emissions.closest_match_explanation: The ingredient 'fresh pasta' is best matched with 'fresh pasta, fettucine spinach' because it is the most specific and least processed option available for fresh pasta. Rule 4 (Consider the Amount of Processing Performed) and Rule 5 (If Multiple Viable Options Have Similar Processing Levels) are applied here, as 'fresh pasta, fettucine spinach' is a direct match for fresh pasta and has a lower emission factor than 'stuffed fresh pasta', which implies more processing.

The ingredient 'garlic' is best matched with 'garlic, raw' because it is the least processed form of garlic available. Rule 4 (Consider the Amount of Processing Performed) is applied here, as 'garlic, raw' is less processed than 'garlic in oil' or 'garlic baguette, frozen'. Rule 1 (Use Realistic CO2 Emission Comparisons Based on Common Sense) is also followed as garlic is a distinct ingredient and should not be matched with 'red onion'.

The ingredient 'onion' is best matched with 'onion, raw' because it is the least processed form of onion available. Rule 4 (Consider the Amount of Processing Performed) is applied here, as 'onion, raw' is less processed than 'onions, chopped and deepfried'. Rule 1 (Use Realistic CO2 Emission Comparisons Based on Common Sense) is also followed as 'red onion' and 'onions, spring, raw' are specific types of onions, and 'onion, raw' is a more general and appropriate match for 'onion'.

The ingredient 'Green Asparagus' is best matched with 'asparagus, green, raw' because it is the most direct and least processed option available. Rule 4 (Consider the Amount of Processing Performed) is applied here, as 'asparagus, green, raw' is less processed than 'asparagus slices'. Rule 1 (Use Realistic CO2 Emission Comparisons Based on Common Sense) is also followed as 'peas, green, frozen' and 'beans, green, raw' are not asparagus.

The ingredient 'Squash' is best matched with 'squash, raw' because it is the most direct and least processed option available. Rule 4 (Consider the Amount of Processing Performed) is applied here. Rule 1 (Use Realistic CO2 Emission Comparisons Based on Common Sense) is also followed as 'squab (pigeon), raw', 'prune, dried plum', and 'gherkin, pickled' are not types of squash.

The ingredient 'fresh basil' is best matched with 'basil, fresh' because it is the most direct and least processed option available. Rule 4 (Consider the Amount of Processing Performed) is applied here, as 'basil, fresh' is less processed than 'basil, dried' or 'pesto'. Rule 1 (Use Realistic CO2 Emission Comparisons Based on Common Sense) is also followed as 'parsley, raw' is not basil.

The ingredient 'cream' is best matched with 'cream, whipping, 38 % fat' because it is the most direct and least processed option available for cream. Rule 4 (Consider the Amount of Processing Performed) is applied here, as 'cream, whipping, 38 % fat' and 'cream, cultured, 18 % fat' are both types of cream, but 'cream, whipping, 38 % fat' has a higher emission factor, as per Rule 5 (If Multiple Viable Options Have Similar Processing Levels). 'Ice cream, dairy (cream based)' and 'cream pastry, layer cake' are final products and not suitable matches according to Rule 3 (Do Not Use Final Meals or Ready Meals as Best Matches).

The ingredient 'grated parmesan' is best matched with 'cheese, hard, parmesan, 32 % fidm.' because it is the most direct and specific match for parmesan cheese. Rule 1 (Use Realistic CO2 Emission Comparisons Based on Common Sense) is applied here, as 'vegan cheese, grated or sliced' and 'tortilla chips, cheese' are not parmesan cheese.

The ingredient 'mozzarella' is best matched with 'cheese, semihard, mozzarella, 30 % fidm.' because it is the most direct and specific match for mozzarella cheese. Rule 1 (Use Realistic CO2 Emission Comparisons Based on Common Sense) is applied here, as 'mozarella sticks' is a processed product and 'goat cheese' is not mozzarella.

The ingredient 'Oil' is best matched with 'olive oil' because it is a common and widely used type of oil, and among the available options, it has the highest emission factor, as per Rule 5 (If Multiple Viable Options Have Similar Processing Levels). All listed oil options are similarly processed, so the tie-breaker rule is applied.
